meaning_mnemonic: At first this looks like a cross in the ground, but it's actually something growing in the <radical>dirt</radical>. It's a little sprout, already rocking three leaves. And it's all thanks to that dirt! When you see this radical, think about how amazing it is that things just, like, grow in the dirt.

This is the <radical>sword</radical> radical. The ノ part is the curvy sword, while the rest is a samurai bowing deeply, like 90 degrees, as he holds that sword — probably before a sword fight. By the way, don't confuse this with the power radical (力). See the difference? In the sword radical (刀), the ノ doesn't pierce through the bowing samurai. (Lucky for him.)

This radical looks like a <radical>narwhal</radical>. See the tail at the bottom, and the majestic narwhal horn poking out at the top? It also looks like the katakana character ナ (na), so you can remember it that way too. Na-na-na-narwhal! Just be careful not to confuse this with the treasure radical (メ). The sideways line for that one is at more of a downward angle, like an "X." But the sideways line for narwhal is horizontal (ナ).
Imagine viewing this one from above — looks like a couple of streets, right? Maybe a three-way intersection at the top there? Well, that's why this is the radical for <radical>street</radical>.
This radical already looks like a pair of <radical>legs</radical>. There's even feet on these legs. That's how you know these are legs and not fins (or something else).

This is the outline of a <radical>head</radical>. A really square head, admittedly, but try to imagine it facing to the right. The left side is the back of the head, and the barb-like part on the right shows the curve of the chin. See the head?
This radical is <radical>treasure</radical> because "X marks the spot," as they say. Doesn't it look like the X on a pirate treasure map? You want to go find that treasure now, right?!

You have a slide supported by a big cross, which makes it so strong it can hold a lot of people at once. How many? A <radical>THOUSAND</radical>! Imagine a thousand people going down this slide. You can hear a voice trying to count them as they go: "ONE! TWO! THREE HUNDRED! FIVE HUNDRED!" and so on. Finally the last person slides down and the voice calls out: "A THOUSAND!" You think it's over, but just as that group finishes, in come another thousand…

This is the top half of a moon peeking out as it begins to rise. When does that happen? In the <radical>evening</radical>! Don't confuse this with the moon radical 月. 夕 is for the evening, when the moon's still low enough to be partly covered (by a mountain, for example).
This is the radical for <radical>child</radical>. Aww, see how they're wearing a cap and have their little arms stretched out? You can almost hear them saying "pick me up!" A very child-like child.

You see two fins around a barb, but when you look closer, you realize those fins are actually two tiny fish. Think how small these fins (and fish) would have to be to look so much smaller than an already small barb. Talk about small fry… Yeah, that's why this is the radical for <radical>small</radical>.

This radical looks like a fancy composite <radical>bow</radical> people would use to shoot at targets and definitely not any normal living animals. See how the middle part is being pulled back? Imagine holding this bow and firing it at a target shaped like a giant alligator-crab monster.
See the <radical>flag</radical> in this radical? There's a pole with a flag on the end of it, blowing in the wind. Basically, this radical looks just like a flag.
These three streaks look like the flowing locks of someone's <radical>hair</radical>. Pretty easy to see and remember that this is the hair radical, right?

If you use your imagination, this radical actually looks like the number "5." You just have to remove the vertical line in the bottom left, plus a few extra ends that stick out here and there. Once you do that, you have an easy way to remember that this radical means <radical>five</radical>.

Remember the guy from the big radical? This is him again, but this time he's so big his head is touching <radical>heaven</radical>. He's looking up and has his arms stretched open toward heaven, and his big hair is poking into those heavenly clouds.

This is the <radical>hand</radical> radical. If you look at the palm of your right hand, the lines in it probably kinda look like the lines in 手. Sure it's not a perfect match, and everyone's got different hands, but basically this radical looks like the lines in your hand. 

You could also think of the horizontal lines in 手 as fingers. That would make for a pretty alien-looking hand, but still a hand… of sorts…

This looks like a stool with a lid on it, but it's actually a desk for <radical>writing</radical>. Do you see it? You can even see the pen sticking up in the middle. Think of all the beautiful writing that's been produced here. Letters, novels, essays — any kind of writing you can think of.

This is the <radical>moon</radical> radical. See how it looks like a crescent moon with a couple of little clouds floating by? Try not to mix this up with the evening radical 夕 — you can see the whole crescent moon this time, so obviously this should be the radical for moon!

There's a stick and a giant toe stuck in the ground. Imagine walking along and seeing these things in your path. What would you do? Most likely come to a complete <radical>stop</radical>. You know, because of the toe. I guess a normal stop sign wasn't good enough, so they also put up this big toe to really get people to stop.

This is the radical for <radical>water</radical>. It's the water radical because it kind of looks like water coming out of a faucet and splashing everywhere. See how it flows off in different directions too? Very water-like! As water-like as a radical can be, anyway…

This is the radical for <radical>fire</radical>. It's got three little flames on top and even a couple logs underneath.

But if it helps you can also focus on the person radical here. See it? It's got things coming off of it... What are those thi— OH MY GOD IT'S FIRE!!! Help, help! Put the fire out! Wait, it's fine… It's just the fire radical.

Remember the big guy who helped you with that big radical? Now you've got his big <radical>DOG</radical>! You know it's a dog because he's lying down, legs all spread out, with his favorite bone right beside his head.

This is the <radical>king</radical> radical. Picture this king sitting on his solid, squarish throne. The top stroke is the high back of the throne. The cross in the middle is his body, with his arms spread out on the arm rests. The bottom stroke is the ground. See him sitting there now, looking all dignified. Talk about a kingly king.

This is a stick going through the <radical>middle</radical> of a mouth. What kind of mouth? Mouth of a cylinder, mouth of a box, a human mouth — whatever kind you want to imagine, as long as the stick is going through the middle of it, since this is the radical for "middle."

What's something useful you can get out of a tree? A <radical>book</radical>! Just cut that book right out of the tree trunk. If you think about it, every tree contains unlimited book potential. It's just a shame they have to be cut down to make the books…

In Japan rice paddies are made up of square fields with irrigation lines going between them. See the four rice paddies with water flowing between and around them? That's why this radical is <radical>rice paddy</radical>.

Add a drop of the sun to something and it will turn it <radical>white</radical>. The sun is really strong, so even a single drop will burn anything white. Why do you think so many beaches are white? Even the drops of sunblock you use to stop the sun's rays is white. So when you think of sun drops, think white.

See the iris in the middle of the eyeball? Remember that there are no round things in kanji, so square things take their place. That makes this a pretty realistic, square <radical>eye</radical>. You just have to squint with your real eyes a bit.

This looks like someone in a standing position with legs planted firmly on the ground, spreading their arms out in a T-pose to maintain balance. So that makes this the radical for <radical>stand</radical>.

This is the <radical>cow</radical> radical. It kind of looks like the long face of a cow, right? Specifically a boy cow, since you can think of that top horizontal line as its horns. Seeing it yet? It's got a little tuft of hair on its head, and some kind of accessory on the horn to your left, so this is a very stylish cow.

(And yes, you may say a "boy cow" isn't a "cow," but we're still calling this a cow. Please don't write in about it — we don't want any beef.)

This is a little triangle that's almost completely closed off. When you want to be alone, you hide in a place where you can be in <radical>private</radical>. That's why this is the private radical. You're closing yourself off to the rest of the world, with just a little peephole.
There's a leaf on top and a stem going down out of it, making this the <radical>leaf</radical> radical. It's a pretty wide and flat leaf, so if it helps you can imagine it as a lily pad leaf.

The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is <radical>sword</radical>, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese <kanji>sword</kanji>? That's right, the most common is a <kanji>katana</kanji>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
reading_mnemonic: So now you have this sweet <kanji>katana</kanji> in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make whooshing noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to <reading>とう</reading>きょう (Tokyo). とうきょう has the best sword and katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to とうきょう.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> radical and the <kanji>dirt</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: Who spends a lot of time in <kanji>dirt</kanji>? <reading>Do</reading>gs (ど) do! Dogs dig in dirt, they roll in dirt, sometimes they try to eat dirt (which isn't so great).

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji is the same as the radical you learned, so it means <kanji>thousand</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember the thousand people going down the slide on a cross in the radical 千? Turns out each one of them was carrying a <kanji>thousand</kanji> <reading>cen</reading>ts (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what a thousand times a thousand cents would come out to. It's quite a lot, actually.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>evening</radical> radical and the <kanji>evening</kanji> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>evening</kanji> is when all the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) come outside to play.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>child</radical> radical and the <kanji>child</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic:
The main reading here is し, so to remember it we'll use this mnemonic:

There is a <kanji>child</kanji> standing in front of you. You look closely at the child but something seems wrong. You rub your eyes and when you open them again, there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in front of you. A sheep?! You yelp, blink again, and it's back to being a child. Are… are all children really just sheep?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>small</radical> radical and the <kanji>small</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>small</kanji> kanji would be the perfect gift to give to the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). The Shougun loves little things, and the <kanji>little</kanji> kanji represents all of that.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>street</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: So you're walking down this <kanji>street</kanji>, and off in the distance you see the silhouette of somebody. A lady. Big, black curly hair and red eyes. It is the street-woman, Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう).

meaning_mnemonic: What's something with <radical>nine</radical> sides? Just add a <radical>drop</radical> and you'll have something that's almost a <kanji>circle</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worthwhile. When you think about a circle, think about Maru all rolled up in a little circle, being super adorable. Don't tell me it doesn't melt your heart just thinking about it. Alternatively, you could also look at this kanji and think of Maru inside of a box, with his little tail sticking out of it. Whatever works best for you, just get yourself to "Maru."

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> you put <radical>barb</radical>s at the bottom of a <radical>slide</radical>. This is your special <kanji>talent</kanji>. When you go down the slide, you fly right past the barbs like some kind of daredevil. Any normal kid would land on the barbs and get hurt, but you have this talent.
reading_mnemonic: But then people start to say that no human could have so much <kanji>talent</kanji>, that you must be a <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). Are you really a talented cyborg?

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <reading>middle</reading> and the kanji <kanji>middle</kanji> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word Chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory.

If you remember back to the radical 中, a stick was stuck in the middle of the mouth of something. Let's say it was your mouth, and when you look up to see who did it, there stands <reading>Chew</reading>bacca. He's even doing his Chewbacca yell. And it isn't a stick in your mouth, it's an arrow from his bowcaster. It just so happens Chewbacca's bowcaster looks just like this kanji too. Go figure.

kanji_to_vocab_info.meaning: Middle Ten Days Of The Month

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>five</radical> radical and the <kanji>five</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Five</kanji> is the number of buildings <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) will knock down. Oh, look! There he goes now.

meaning_mnemonic: Just imagine a beast with a <radical>lid</radical> for a head and <radical>fins</radical> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <kanji>six</kanji> is the devil's number.
reading_mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word <reading>rock</reading>. 

So, think about the devil and the devil's number. What is often associated with those things? Why, <reading>rock</reading> (ろく) and roll is. Imagine the lid-head fin-legged beast suddenly blasting out rock music in the middle of his destructive mayhem.

meaning_mnemonic: Here we have a <radical>head</radical> with a <radical>lid</radical> in it, near the top. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <kanji>yen</kanji> coins, the currency of Japan. Jackpot! And all those yen coins have a nice <kanji>round</kanji> shape, naturally.
reading_mnemonic: What does the word <kanji>yen</kanji> sound like? It sounds like <reading>えん</reading>. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a "ye" sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an "e" sound, which is why yen = えん!

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>heaven</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>heaven</kanji>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Heaven</kanji>... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only <reading>ten</reading> (てん) percent!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>hand</radical> radical and the <kanji>hand</kanji> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading て we will use the word "television." You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little <reading>te</reading>levisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>writing</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>writing</kanji> as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You always put <kanji>writing</kanji> on your <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん) to keep them from getting eaten by the bun <reading>mon</reading>ster (もん). What kind of writing? Usually it's just an X to show the monster these buns are off-limits. (In fact, it kind of looks like the X part in 文. Hmm…)

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> radical and <kanji>sun</kanji> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <kanji>day</kanji> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
reading_mnemonic:
There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. 

The <kanji>sun</kanji> is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (にち), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.

kanji_to_vocab_info.reading: おたんじょうびおめでとう

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> kanji is made up of the <radical>moon</radical> radical. This kanji is also used to mean <kanji>month</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> really <reading>gets</reading> (げつ) to your <reading>guts</reading> (がつ). Staring at the moon for too long will give you terrible indigestion, so be careful!

meaning_mnemonic: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <radical>tree</radical> and <kanji>tree</kanji> are the same in looks and meaning.
reading_mnemonic: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Suddenly, you trip and fall. The trees start to <reading>mock</reading> (もく) you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked as you pull yourself up off the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>water</radical> radical and the <kanji>water</kanji> kanji are the same.
reading_mnemonic: Imagine a lake (i.e. a whole bunch of <kanji>water</kanji>). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire <reading>swi</reading>ng (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you are swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very <reading>swee</reading>t. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fire</radical> radical and the <kanji>fire</kanji> kanji are the same as each other.
reading_mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word <reading>car</reading>.

For this kanji, when we think <kanji>fire</kanji>, we ought to think of something on fire. What's on fire? It's obviously your very own <reading>car</reading> (か)! Oh Goddd NOOO!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dog</radical> radical and <kanji>dog</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: Every <kanji>dog</kanji> likes to <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>noo</reading>dles (いぬ). Like that movie where the dogs share a noodle and end up kissing, right? So when you see 犬, just imagine how those two eat noodles.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> radical and the <kanji>king</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>king</kanji> you need to say, "<reading>Oh</reading> (おう) King! Oh King, oh no, oh why are you looking at me like that? Oh King... you aren't going to chop off my head are you? OH NO!"

meaning_mnemonic: There are two <radical>mountains</radical> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <kanji>exit</kanji> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.
reading_mnemonic: As you're trying to <kanji>exit</kanji> this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he <reading>shoots you</reading> (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.

kanji_to_vocab_info.meaning: To Go Out Into The World

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Narwhal</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s are on the <kanji>right</kanji> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.

See how the "mouth" radical is to the right of the "narwhal" radical? That should help you remember that this means <kanji>right</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: How did we know to look from the <kanji>right</kanji>, though? Because the <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう) figured it out. Youths think in ways that older people usually don't. That's why they can see the swirls on cereal, hear the music behind noise, and of course, look at things from the right side.

meaning_mnemonic: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <radical>mouth</radical> now has your <radical>legs</radical> inside it. You've bent your body in all the wrong ways to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <kanji>four</kanji> sides.
reading_mnemonic: Now that you have <kanji>four</kanji> sides, you look like a four-sided animal: the <reading>shee</reading>p (し). Look at yourself in the mirror and see an adorable four-sided sheep looking back at you. Imagine yourself with perfectly square wool. (You can only see four sides because mirrors aren't 3D. So you're a flat, cartoonish sheep.)

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Narwhal</radical>s do <radical>construction</radical> with their <kanji>left</kanji> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!
reading_mnemonic: In their <kanji>left</kanji> hands, the narwhals all hold <reading>saw</reading>s (さ). That's because the ice for their homes is already there, so they just need to saw away at them to make the shapes they want. Narwhal construction is actually very simple.

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>book</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>book</kanji> as well.

Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <kanji>origin</kanji>, <kanji>real</kanji>, and <kanji>main</kanji>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Book</kanji>s are one of the best ways to <reading>hone</reading> (ほん) your intellect, you know?

meaning_mnemonic: There is a line on the <radical>ground</radical> so you <radical>stop</radical>, making a giant sign pop up that says <kanji>CORRECT</kanji>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing. Good on you.
reading_mnemonic: You did the <kanji>correct</kanji> thing, so here's your reward: a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) from the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう) himself!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> has a big <radical>drop</radical> of liquid in his hand... but then he bounces it! The drop was really a <kanji>ball</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: When he's done playing with it, the king gives his <kanji>ball</kanji> to <reading>Tama</reading>ra (たま), the resident ball girl, for safekeeping.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice paddy</radical> radical and the <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading た, we use the word "taco."

You're in the rice field... but when you lean down to examine the rice more closely, you see that it's not rice that's growing, it's a bunch of little <reading>ta</reading>cos (た), blossoming out of the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>white</radical> and the kanji <kanji>white</kanji> are the same.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>white</kanji> team was the first to be able to <reading>hack</reading> (はく) the <kanji>white</kanji> iPhone.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> radical and <kanji>eye</kanji> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>eyes</kanji> are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... "<reading>Mehhhhhh</reading> (め)!"

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>stand</radical> and the kanji <kanji>stand</kanji> are the same thing, so now you know them both.
reading_mnemonic: Think of someone who has to <kanji>stand</kanji> up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the <reading>Ritz</reading> (りつ).

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. It repeats what comes before it.

To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a <radical>prison</radical> with <radical>drop</radical>s of water dripping over and over in it. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again, driving the prisoners nuts. But it never stops. It just repeats over and over.
reading_mnemonic:
This symbol doesn't really have a name, but it's sometimes called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way:

Your mom is the <kanji>repeater</kanji>. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling "<reading>No ma</reading> (のま)!" but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track, never stopping, repeating forever.

examples.en: My roommate goes up to the loft.
examples.ja: ルームメイトはロフトに上る。

examples.en: The "up" button for the elevator is right here.
examples.ja: エレベーターの「上る」ボタンは、ここです。

examples.en: I saw salmon swimming upstream.
examples.ja: サケが川を上っているのをみた。

meaning_mnemonic: This word means <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary>. You can tell this word is a verb because it ends with an う sound (る, in this case). Its meaning is similar to the meaning of the 上 kanji, which is "above." So this word is all about moving "above" something (in other words, climbing!)
reading_mnemonic:
上る consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, so it will use the kun'yomi reading of the kanji. For 上, there are multiple kun'yomi readings, and you didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You want <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary> the mountain, but a gruff old man grabs your shoulder and says "<reading>No bo</reading>y, you ain't climbing that thing, not today." If you're not a boy, think about how weird it is that he called you a boy. If you are a grown man, think how you wish he called you "dude" or something, not "boy." If you're a boy, well... think about how appropriate it is that he said "no boy."

examples.en: The samurai raised his sword out of the blue.
examples.ja: いきなりサムライが刀を上げた。

examples.en: I want to buy a sword in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本で刀をかいたいんです。

examples.en: Isn't this little sword so cute?
examples.ja: この小さい刀、かわいくない？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. I'm hoping you already know this word - that will make everything much easier. It's <reading>かたな</reading> (you know what a katana is, right?).

examples.en: That tomato has some dirt on it.
examples.ja: そのトマト、土がついてるよ。

examples.en: This is soil from Mt. Fuji.
examples.ja: これはふじ山の土なんだよ。

examples.en: The mole was going into the ground.
examples.ja: モグラが土に入っていった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

土 generally refers to <vocabulary>dirt</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>soil</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>earth</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: 

You look through the soil. You're trying to find something. As you dig and sift, you come across not one but <reading>two chee</reading>ses (つち). Pull them out of the ground and put them in your mouth. How do the two cheeses taste and compare?

examples.en: One liter is a thousand milliliters.
examples.ja: 一リットルとは、千ミリリットルのことだ。

examples.en: That French person is a one-in-a-thousand genius.
examples.ja: そのフランス人は、千に一人の天才です。

examples.en: It takes about 1,000 days.
examples.ja: 千日くらいかかりますね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Normally a single kanji making up a word like this means it will use the kun'yomi readings. Numbers are generally the exception, though, which means this word uses the on'yomi reading. If you learned the kanji, then you should already know this!

examples.en: I saw the moon last night.
examples.ja: 夕べ、月をみた。

examples.en: Dinner last night was onion curry.
examples.ja: 夕べのディナーは玉ねぎのカレーでした。

examples.en: There's an event called "Wine Evening" in May.
examples.ja: 五月に「ワインの夕べ」というイベントがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: I spent all <kanji>evening</kanji> in <reading>be</reading>(べ)d  <vocabulary>last night</vocabulary>. It was a really chill <vocabulary>evening</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When hiragana is attached to a kanji, you can usually assume that that kanji is going to be read using the kun'yomi reading, which is exactly what's going on with this word as well. By learning this word's kanji you've also learned the reading for this word.

examples.en: The girl in the white dress is Rachel.
examples.ja: 白のドレスの女の子がレイチェルです。

examples.en: This girl is a five-year-old genius programmer.
examples.ja: この女の子は五才の天才プログラマーだ。

examples.en: I'm not a girl. I'm an adult woman. Got it?
examples.ja: わたしは女の子じゃない。一人の大人の女。わかった？

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary>.

This word has two kanji with hiragana stuck in the middle. That hiragana is the particle の. This time, it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after it.

女の子 is a casual word for young girls, like kids or teenagers. Sometimes it can also refer to adult women, but only to playfully or affectionately highlight their youthful or girlish qualities.
reading_mnemonic:
Since there's hiragana in here, you can bet that these kanji will use the kun'yomi readings. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 女. You might even remember the one for 子, but here's a mnemonic just in case:

When you need to remember the kun'yomi reading for 子, just think about how a child stole your <reading>co</reading>at (こ). You gave it to her because she looked cold, but then she ran off down the street and left you shouting, "Coat! Coat! That 子 has my coat!"

examples.en: That lion's child is called Simba.
examples.ja: そのライオンの子はシンバという。

examples.en: You aren’t my real child.
examples.ja: あなたは、わたしのほんとうの子ではないの。

examples.en: Don’t you think my kid looks similar to Beyoncé?
examples.ja: わたしの子、ビヨンセににているとおもわない？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You saw a <vocabulary>child</vocabulary> and gave her your <reading>co</reading>at (こ). The kid looked all cold, so you gave her your coat. Children never want to wear proper warm clothing when they should, then they end up shivering their butts off and needing to wear a parent's oversized coat. Fortunately you were there to give this 子 your coat.

examples.en: The ladies' room is over there.
examples.ja: そっちは女子トイレですよ。

examples.en: I gave a women's professional wrestling ticket as a present.
examples.ja: 女子プロレスのチケットをプレゼントした。

examples.en: I was the captain of the women's volleyball team.
examples.ja: 女子バレーボールのチームキャプテンでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary>!

女子 is a relatively formal word commonly used in contexts where classification or categorization by gender is used, such as in sports or school settings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Small tomatoes are delicious.
examples.ja: 小さいトマトはおいしいですよね。

examples.en: In this class, there are kids who are still small while there are kids who are as tall as adults.
examples.ja: このクラスには、まだ小さい子もいれば、大人のように大きい子もいる。

examples.en: This dress is too small for me.
examples.ja: このドレスは、わたしには小さすぎる。

meaning_mnemonic: This kanji has hiragana attached and ends with an い sound. That means it's probably an adjective (and it is!). So, if you take the kanji 小 and its meaning (small), you can figure out the adjective version of it. What is the adjective version of "small?" Actually, it's the same thing: <vocabulary>small</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the ちい portion:

When you think of the word <vocabulary>small</vocabulary>, try to think of this <reading>chee</reading>se <reading>ea</reading>tery (ちい). You go inside, and all of their cheeses are so small. They hand you a magnifying glass to see all the cheeses. You look at them and exclaim: "Why are these cheeses so small???"

examples.en: Check here with a circle, please.
examples.ja: ここに丸でチェックして下さい。

examples.en: My type is someone who is good at drawing circles.
examples.ja: 丸をかくのが上手な人がタイプです。

examples.en: People get wide-eyed when someone proposes to them as a surprise.
examples.ja: 人はサプライズでプロポーズされると目が丸になるものなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This vocab word and the kanji that makes it have the same meaning: <vocabulary>Circle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading you learned for this kanji is the kun'yomi one. Since this vocab word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Guess what? That means you already know it!

examples.en: I want a round ball.
examples.ja: 丸いボールがほしい。

examples.en: This restaurant only serves round-shaped fruit.
examples.ja: このレストランには丸いフルーツしかありません。

examples.en: Isn't this ball a bit too round?
examples.ja: この玉、ちょっと丸すぎませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: With an い on the end, you can guess that this word is an い-adjective. What is the adjective version of the kanji <kanji>丸</kanji>? "Circle" becomes <vocabulary>circular</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spherical</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>round</vocabulary>. This, compared to another similar word (円), is more general purpose and can be used with 3D spherical objects as well.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the reading you learned for the kanji <kanji>丸</kanji>, though you'll need to tack the い onto the end too.

examples.en: I am five years old.
examples.ja: わたしは五才です。

examples.en: My first kiss was when I was 16 years old.
examples.ja: ファーストキスは十六才のときでした。

examples.en: Dad's present for his fiftieth birthday was a mountain of Pokémon cards.
examples.ja: パパの50才のバースデープレゼントは、ポケモンカードの山でした。

meaning_mnemonic:
Although this word consists of one kanji that is all alone, it doesn't share its meaning with the parent kanji. But the meanings are similar in a way. This word means <vocabulary>years old</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>age</vocabulary>. With more years comes more <kanji>talent</kanji>, right? That's why this word means "years old" and not "talent," like the parent kanji.

You can stick this word onto numbers to say how old someone is!

Special note for all of you advanced learners out there. When discussing age, 〜歳 is the original and correct kanji to use. Because 〜才 is easier to write and has the same reading, it became mainstream. You'll see it used in writing today, especially in elementary schools. In formal writing though, you'll always want to use 〜歳, which you'll learn later on.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it! Don't try to type the 〜 part though.

examples.en: Let's go inside quickly.
examples.ja: はやく中に入ろう。

examples.en: Is Rachel in this group?
examples.ja: このグループの中に、レイチェルはいますか？

examples.en: A woman in a bikini came out of the river.
examples.ja: 川の中からビキニの女が出てきた。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>middle</kanji> kanji is used as a word, it means <vocabulary>inside</vocabulary>. When you're in the middle of something, it means you're <vocabulary>in</vocabulary> that thing!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

There's a sound coming from <kanji>inside</kanji> the wall. It sounds like a knock, knock, knock noise. You break down the wall, and there's some creepy dude standing inside. He is the <reading>knocker</reading> (なか).

examples.en: This curry is delicious.
examples.ja: このカレー、中々おいしいですね。

examples.en: The test in January was quite difficult.
examples.ja: 一月のテストは中々むずかしかった。

examples.en: This card is rare and it costs about 1,000 dollars.
examples.ja: このカードは中々レアなので一千ドルぐらいしますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The 々 symbol just repeats the kanji that comes before it. In other words, 中々 is the same as 中中. Easy! So with 中々, you have <kanji>middle</kanji> x2. When something is more middle than middle itself, it's <vocabulary>rather</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>quite</vocabulary> something. Why? I guess because those are all good middle-level intensifiers.

中々 can be used in positive or negative ways. In a positive way, it usually means something is better than expected, like 中々おいしい (quite delicious). But it's really versatile and could also mean "a little," "very," or "completely" depending on the situation. It might even sound condescending, so be careful how you use it! In a negative sense, you can use it when something is more difficult than expected, like in 中々できない (can't be done easily).
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, since it's like putting two single kanji together rather than a true jukugo word. To learn the kun'yomi reading, take a look at this mnemonic: 

From the middle of the middle comes a sound. It is a knocking sound. Knock. Knock. Knock. You open up the walls around this thing. Then you open up the second set of walls (middle of the middle). Inside is an old man, who identifies himself as "the knocker." You go inside of him and find another knocker as well. That's why it's a <reading>knocker knocker</reading> (なかなか).

examples.en: On May 1st, I returned to New York.
examples.ja: 五月一日にニューヨークへかえりました。

examples.en: I'm planning to propose on Mt. Fuji in May.
examples.ja: 五月にふじ山でプロポーズするつもりなんです。

examples.en: May in Japan is known for "Golden Week."
examples.ja: 日本で五月といえばゴールデンウィークです。

meaning_mnemonic: The moon kanji also represents a month, so when you have five of these months, what month of the year is it? That would be <vocabulary>May</vocabulary>, the greatest month of the year (because it has towel day in it!).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 月 has two on'yomi readings, but it always uses the がつ reading in the names of the months, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

<vocabulary>May</vocabulary> is when you and your buddies get together to eat <reading>Go</reading>dzilla <reading>guts</reading> (ごがつ). You go hunting for Godzilla just for his delicious guts, and then eat them with your friends. Yummy.

examples.en: Is the 5th okay for the meeting?
examples.ja: ミーティングは五日でもだいじょうぶ？

examples.en: There are five days left until the event.
examples.ja: イベントまであと五日。

examples.en: Oh, that girl? I got dumped five days after we went out on a date.
examples.ja: ああ、あの女の子？デートして五日でフラれたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Day five</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>fifth day</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

On the <vocabulary>fifth day</vocabulary> I have to <reading>eat</reading> (いつ) five <reading>ca</reading>rs (か). Now imagine yourself eating five cars. How did you manage to get past the first one? I'm impressed.

examples.en: I only walked fifty meters.
examples.ja: 五十メートルしかウォーキングしなかった。

examples.en: Mom turned fifty on the 8th.
examples.ja: ママは八日に五十になった。

examples.en: Portland's Caucasian population is higher than 50%.
examples.ja: ポートランドの白人人口は五十パーセントよりも上なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: What happens when you have ten five times? You get <vocabulary>fifty</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for this word too, which means you should already know how to read this word.

examples.en: I got five chocolates on Valentine's Day.
examples.ja: バレンタインデーにチョコレートを五つもらった。

examples.en: Let's divide into five groups.
examples.ja: 五つのグループにわかれましょう。

examples.en: It's impossible to collect five eyeballs in one day.
examples.ja: 一日で目玉を五つもあつめるなんてムリですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: From previous number + つ words, you can probably guess that this word means <vocabulary>five things</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading of this word is the kun'yomi reading of the kanji <kanji>五</kanji>, meaning you didn't learn it when you learned the parent kanji reading. To remember this word, think of it this way:

You have <vocabulary>five things</vocabulary>. What do you have to do with them? You need to <reading>eat</reading> (いつ) them. Just imagine having five delicious things to eat, sticking each on one finger of your hand, and then eating them one after another. And make sure to count down from five while doing it!

examples.en: This smartphone screen size is five inches.
examples.ja: このスマホのスクリーンの大きさは五インチです。

examples.en: One of the five floors is a cafeteria.
examples.ja: 五フロアのうちの一フロアはカフェテリアです。

examples.en: After five games, finally there was a first score.
examples.ja: 五ゲームおわって、やっとファーストスコアが入った。

meaning_mnemonic: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: <vocabulary>Five</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since numbers are an exception, this word is read using the on'yomi reading even though it's made from a single kanji all alone. Luckily for you, you learned the reading for this word when you learned the parent kanji.

examples.en: There are six spoons.
examples.ja: スプーンが六つあります。

examples.en: The meeting room has one table and six office chairs.
examples.ja: ミーティングルームには、テーブルが一つと、オフィスチェアが六つあります。

examples.en: I ordered six wine glasses.
examples.ja: ワイングラスは六つオーダーしておいたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Any number with a つ attached to it means you are counting that number of things. In this case, it's <vocabulary>six things</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you do that:

What are the <vocabulary>six things</vocabulary> that you need to count? This time you are counting six cows. The reason it's six is because you wanted exactly six <reading>moo</reading>s (むっ). No more, no less. You're very particular about your moos.

examples.en: I went to the United States in June.
examples.ja: 六月にアメリカにいきました。

examples.en: June is the wedding season.
examples.ja: 六月はウェディングシーズンです。

examples.en: We're heading into June soon.
examples.ja: もうすぐ六月に入りますね。

meaning_mnemonic: Since the kanji 月 means both "moon" and "month," what is the sixth month of the year? January, February, March, April, May, <vocabulary>June</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 月 has two on'yomi readings, but it always uses the がつ reading in the names of the months, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

<vocabulary>June</vocabulary> always gives you <reading>rock</reading> <reading>guts</reading> (ろくがつ). In June, your guts mysteriously become as hard as rock, which makes for terrible indigestion.

examples.en: Where were you on April 6th?
examples.ja: あなたは四月六日に、どこにいましたか？

examples.en: I spent six days out of my ten-day vacation playing video games.
examples.ja: 十日のバケーションのうち六日はずっとゲームをしてました。

examples.en: I take a sauna every six days.
examples.ja: 六日ごとにサウナに入ってます。

meaning_mnemonic: It's the kanji for six and day. Put them together and you have the <vocabulary>sixth day</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>day six</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This is an exception, though. When you're counting days (at least one through ten), the kun'yomi readings are used. So let's think about that sixth day - what does it entail?

On the <vocabulary>sixth day</vocabulary> of your roadtrip, you've finally arrived at your destination. You get out of your car and tell it, "<reading>Muy</reading> (むい) bien <reading>car</reading> (か), muy bien!".

examples.en: The ramen was 16 dollars.
examples.ja: ラーメンが十六ドルもしたよ。

examples.en: I've just turned sixteen.
examples.ja: 十六になったばかりです。

examples.en: There's a drone sixteen meters overhead.
examples.ja: 十六メートル上にドローンがいる。

meaning_mnemonic: You have ten and six (not to be confused with six tens!). When you have ten and six, you have a total of <vocabulary>sixteen</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

examples.en: There are many sixes in my social security number.
examples.ja: わたしのソーシャルセキュリティナンバーには六がたくさんあります。

examples.en: This restaurant has six types of sauce.
examples.ja: このレストランには六タイプのソースがあります。

examples.en: Why do you need a giant six-meter sofa?
examples.ja: なんで六メートルの大きなソファがいるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. Numbers, as you know, are the exception to this rule. They usually use the on'yomi reading, and the on'yomi reading is the one you learned along with this kanji, meaning you should be good to go!

examples.en: This dress was 5,000 yen.
examples.ja: このドレスは五千円でした。

examples.en: It will be 1,000 yen for two of these.
examples.ja: こちら二つで千円になります。

examples.en: At this rate, five dollars is about 800 yen.
examples.ja: このレートだと、五ドルは８００円くらいですね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Be sure to omit the 〜 in your answer as it is only a placeholder for a number.

examples.en: This skirt is 1000 yen.
examples.ja: このスカートは、千円です。

examples.en: Does the thousand-yen lunch set come with dessert?
examples.ja: 千円のランチセットにはデザートがついてますか？

examples.en: The cost of tennis is 1,000 yen a month.
examples.ja: テニスにかかるコストは月に千円です。

meaning_mnemonic: A thousand of these yen things makes this word <vocabulary>one thousand yen</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since you know the on'yomi readings of these two kanji, you should know the reading for this vocab word as well!

examples.en: It's probably a message from Mom in heaven.
examples.ja: きっと天にいるママからのメッセージだよ。

examples.en: There are probably a lot of people in heaven.
examples.ja: きっと天には、たくさんの人がいるんでしょう。

examples.en: That dog must have been a heavenly messenger.
examples.ja: あの犬、きっと天のつかいだったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it would normally use the kun'yomi reading. The kanji that makes this word only has one important reading, though, and that happens to be the on'yomi. Since you learned the on'yomi reading for this kanji, you've already learned the reading for this word.

examples.en: That girl is a genius.
examples.ja: あの女の子は天才だ。

examples.en: I want to be called a genius tennis-player someday.
examples.ja: いつか天才テニスプレイヤーとよばれたいです。

examples.en: That gorilla is definitely a genius.
examples.ja: そのゴリラは、まぎれもなく天才だ。

meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>heaven</kanji> has given you <kanji>talent</kanji>, you must be a <vocabulary>genius</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

examples.en: The king raised his hand and said, "Good morning!"
examples.ja: 王は手を上げて「おはよう！」といった。

examples.en: Can I hold your hand?
examples.ja: 手をつないでもいい？

examples.en: Dad's arms are all shaggy.
examples.ja: パパの手はモジャモジャだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>hand</kanji>, and the word means <vocabulary>hand</vocabulary> too! It can also be used to refer to your whole <vocabulary>arm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Since this is a body part, the kun'yomi reading usually takes priority. That means you learned the kun'yomi reading already when you learned the kanji.

examples.en: I'm not the best at playing the guitar, but I'm pretty good at the piano.
examples.ja: ギターは下手ですが、ピアノは中々上手ですよ。

examples.en: I want to go to a spa instead of getting a bad massage.
examples.ja: 下手なマッサージより、スパにいきたいよ。

examples.en: I can't go on a date with someone who isn't good at Bananagrams. I'm sorry.
examples.ja: わたし、バナナグラムが下手な人とはデートにいけないの。ごめんなさい。

meaning_mnemonic: Think of someone holding out their hand at shoulder level. Anything above that equals "skillful." Everything <kanji>below</kanji> that <kanji>hand</kanji> equals <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary>. That's why "below hand" means <vocabulary>unskilled</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bad at</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
Sometimes kanji have exceptional readings that are neither on'yomi nor kun'yomi, and this is one of them. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:

If you're <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bad at</vocabulary> something and you complain about it, then you're just a <reading>hater</reading> (へた). Don't be a hater; get better.

examples.en: Jenny, you're good at skiing.
examples.ja: ジェニーさん、スキーが上手ですね。

examples.en: Is there anyone here who can do a good Keanu Reeves impression?
examples.ja: キアヌ・リーブスのモノマネが上手な人、いませんか？

examples.en: "Nice to meet you." "Nice to meet you. Your Japanese is good!"
examples.ja: 「はじめまして。」「はじめまして。にほんご上手ですね！」

meaning_mnemonic: Think of someone holding out their hand. This is average. Things rated below the hand are things you're bad at. Things rated <kanji>above</kanji> the <kanji>hand</kanji> are things you're <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Both of these kanji use on'yomi readings, though 手 uses an on'yomi reading you didn't learn with the kanji. It's a rare reading, so it wasn't included (and we just have to deal with exceptions like this as we go along). To remember the reading for this word, here's a mnemonic:

What are you good at? You're really <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary> taking <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう) to the <reading>zoo</reading> (ず). No one else can take Joe to the zoo—he gets mad and throws them into the animal enclosures. But you? Joe trusts you.

examples.en: You're great at writing.
examples.ja: 文をかくのが上手ですね。

examples.en: I enter data and sentences.
examples.ja: データや文を入力します。

examples.en: AI writes better sentences than people these days.
examples.ja: さいきんはAIのほうが人々よりも上手な文をかく。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

By itself, 文 can also just mean <vocabulary>sentence</vocabulary>, especially in grammatical contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses one of the readings you learned for the kanji: ぶん. You can remember this by thinking how whenever you're working on your writing, eating a <reading>bun</reading> (ぶん) helps you write better sentences.

examples.en: The sun will come out soon.
examples.ja: そろそろ日が出ますよ。

examples.en: The date the puppy comes is the 3rd.
examples.ja: 子犬がくる日は三日です。

examples.en: I lost my passport on the day I came to Japan.
examples.ja: 日本にきた日にパスポートをなくした。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Take note that this word means both "sun" and "day," though. Why? because the sun takes a day to go around and come back!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: 

What do you feel from the sun? You feel the <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ).

examples.en: The moon was beautiful last night.
examples.ja: 夕べは月がきれいでしたね。

examples.en: I won't be in Japan that month. Sorry.
examples.ja: その月は、日本にいないんです。ごめんなさい。

examples.en: The moon you see from the top of this mountain is beautiful.
examples.ja: この山の上からみる月は、きれいです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

Look up at that big, bright moon. You have to open it up and take what's inside. To do that, you are required to have <reading>two key</reading>s (つき), and they have to be turned at the same time. Imagine you and a friend both turning your keys on opposite sides of the moon to open up the center.

examples.en: I will be fifty years old in October.
examples.ja: 十月に五十才になります。

examples.en: Shiitake mushrooms in October are delicious.
examples.ja: 十月のシイタケはおいしいですよ。

examples.en: Still in a bikini in October!?
examples.ja: 十月なのにまだビキニ！？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji for "moon" and "month" are the same, probably because a moon cycle takes approximately a month to occur. So, what is the tenth moon cycle of the year? That would be the awesome month <vocabulary>October</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>October</vocabulary> gives you <reading>jew</reading>el <reading>guts</reading> (じゅうがつ). In October, your guts magically produce jewels, which you collect to make some pretty awesome Halloween costumes.

examples.en: The wedding reception was in January.
examples.ja: ウェディングパーティーは一月でした。

examples.en: In January, we have a meeting with the designer.
examples.ja: 一月は、デザイナーとのミーティングがある。

examples.en: I decided to leave this hotel in January.
examples.ja: 一月には、このホテルを出て行くことにしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Since the kanji 月 mean both moon and month (because a moon cycle is about a month, presumably), what is the number one month? In English we have an actual name for it, and that name is <vocabulary>January</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 月 has two on'yomi readings, but it always uses the がつ reading in the names of the months, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

<vocabulary>January</vocabulary> always gives you <reading>itchy</reading> <reading>guts</reading> (いちがつ). It's a weird affliction that comes around every January and makes your guts incredibly itchy. Probably due to all that overindulgence over the new year.

examples.en: Valentine's Day is in February.
examples.ja: バレンタインデーは二月だよ。

examples.en: February in Japan is quite cold.
examples.ja: 日本の二月は中々さむいですよ。

examples.en: There are lots of sales for coats and jackets in February.
examples.ja: 二月はコートとジャケットのセールがたくさんあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji 月 means both month and moon (because moon cycles take about a month, presumably). So, what is the number two month? It's not January... it's not March... it's <vocabulary>February</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 月 has two on'yomi readings, but it always uses the がつ reading in the names of the months, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

<vocabulary>February</vocabulary> is the month when somebody gives you a <reading>knee</reading> in the <reading>guts</reading> (にがつ). A complete stranger comes around each February just to knee you right in the guts. Ouch! That's why February is your least favourite month.

examples.en: Is this a cherry tree?
examples.ja: これはサクラの木ですか？

examples.en: This table is made of wood.
examples.ja: このテーブルは木で、できてます。

examples.en: I want to build a tree house on that tree over there.
examples.ja: あの木の上にツリーハウスをつくりたい。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

You walk up to the tree. You have to get inside, because it takes you someplace secret. So, you take out your <reading>key</reading> (き) and put it in the slot, opening the door in the tree so you can slip inside.

examples.en: Can I get water or juice?
examples.ja: 水かジュースをもらえますか。

examples.en: The river water was a beautiful emerald green.
examples.ja: 川の水はきれいなエメラルドグリーンだった。

examples.en: May I have some water from Mt. Fuji instead of ordinary water?
examples.ja: ふつうの水じゃなくて、ふじ山の水をもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

Be sure you always carry water when visiting the <reading>me zoo</reading> (みず). That's a zoo with rows and rows of cages of... me. And I'm thirsty!

examples.en: I lit the candle.
examples.ja: キャンドルに火をつけた。

examples.en: It took five days to extinguish the fire.
examples.ja: 火がきえるのに五日かかりました。

examples.en: You're good at lighting the stove.
examples.ja: ストーブの火をつけるのが上手ですね。

meaning_mnemonic: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: <vocabulary>fire</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

What comes off of <vocabulary>fire</vocabulary>? Lots and lots of <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ). Feel it coming off the fire, touching and warming your face.

examples.en: Mt. Fuji is a volcano.
examples.ja: ふじ山は、火山です。

examples.en: There is some fire coming out of the top of the volcano.
examples.ja: 火山の上から火が出ている。

examples.en: There are many volcanoes in Hawaii.
examples.ja: ハワイには火山がたくさんありますよね。

meaning_mnemonic: A fire mountain is probably what you think it is: A <vocabulary>volcano</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku (sequential voicing).

examples.en: My pet is a dog.
examples.ja: ぼくのペットは犬です。

examples.en: Is this dog a Chihuahua?
examples.ja: この犬は、チワワですか？

examples.en: My dog ​​is about the size of a lion.
examples.ja: うちの犬、ライオンくらいの大きさなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This vocab made up of a single kanji shares its meaning with said single kanji. That meaning is <vocabulary>dog</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

examples.en: The puppy is cute.
examples.ja: 子犬は、かわいい。

examples.en: Puppies are a lot of work to train.
examples.ja: 子犬はトレーニングがたいへんです。

examples.en: Let’s pretend we’re puppies!
examples.ja: 子犬ごっこをしましょうよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>puppy</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: Even though this is a jukugo word, it doesn't use the on'yomi readings. Fortunately you learned the kun'yomi readings with the vocab words 子 (こ) and 犬 (いぬ). Just think of 子犬 as those two words mashed together to remember this one.

examples.en: I am the king.
examples.ja: わたしが王だ。

examples.en: The king and the queen are a powerful couple.
examples.ja: 王と女王は力のあるカップルだ。

examples.en: This is the king's private jet.
examples.ja: これは王のプライベートジェットですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.

examples.en: "Good morning!" the prince said.
examples.ja: 「おはよう！」と、王子がいった。

examples.en: The prince had a puppy when he was little.
examples.ja: 王子は小さいころに子犬をかってた。

examples.en: My child constantly prays to heaven for a hug from the prince.
examples.ja: うちの子は王子にハグしてもらいたい、と天にいのってばかりよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>king</kanji>'s <kanji>child</kanji> is the <vocabulary>prince</vocabulary>. Someday he'll be the 王, if he's lucky, but right now he's just the king's child, a.k.a. the prince!

If you prefer some grammatical details, you can try to remember that when a word consists of two kanji, sometimes the first kanji has a possessive relation to the second. In this case, 王 possesses 子, making it the king's child. Historically, male children had priority in royal succession, so I guess that's why this word means "prince."
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also take note that the reading for 子 (し) is changed to じ.

That said, this reading can be easy to confuse with other similar words, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

The <vocabulary>prince</vocabulary> is always saying "<reading>Ohh</reading>, <reading>Je</reading>sus (おうじ), please let me be king!" In fact, the prince probably says "Ohh, Jesus" to ask for help at least once a day.

examples.en: It is the queen's necklace.
examples.ja: それは、女王のネックレスです。

examples.en: The Queen's book has become a bestseller.
examples.ja: 女王の本はベストセラーになった。

examples.en: I was a penpal with Queen Elizabeth for fifty years.
examples.ja: エリザベス女王とは、五十年もペンパルでした。

meaning_mnemonic: The woman king is the queen. You know this because the woman who comes before the king must be the queen. Imagine this woman in front, leading the king around. Only a queen could do that! For a more technical explanation, just remember that when a word consists of two kanji characters, the first kanji often modifies the second. In this case, 女 modifies 王, making it the woman king, a.k.a. the queen!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. That said, this reading can be easy to confuse with other similar words, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

The <vocabulary>queen</vocabulary> is named <reading>Jo</reading>-Ann (じょ), or Jo for short, and she's always joking. Hey, wait a minute. Jo… king. 女… king. Jo… おう!! 女王! Get it? When you think of the queen, just remember how much she loves joking (女王).

examples.en: The princess is always right.
examples.ja: 王女はいつでも正しい。

examples.en: The princess likes bingo.
examples.ja: 王女はビンゴがすきです。

examples.en: Is there a princess in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本に王女はいますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The king's woman (or girl) is the princess. You know she's the princess because she comes after the king — she's just his daughter and doesn't have as much power. Imagine the king with a young woman following after him. Must be the princess! If you prefer some grammatical details, you can try to remember that when a word consists of two kanji, sometimes the first kanji has a possessive relation to the second. In this case, 王 possesses 女, making it the king's girl (almost like "daddy's girl"). In other words, the princess!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. That said, this reading can be easy to confuse with other similar words, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

The <vocabulary>princess</vocabulary> is named <reading>Jo</reading>-Ann Jr. (じょ), or Jo for short , and she loves making people say "Ohh, Jo!" (王女) by sneaking up and scaring them. Whenever you think of the princess now, imagine how many times people have screamed "Ohh, Jo!" at her.

examples.en: Please leave using that exit.
examples.ja: あちらの出口から出てください。

examples.en: It looks like you have to sneeze, but can't.
examples.ja: くしゃみが出そうで出ない。

examples.en: Let's get out of the restaurant.
examples.ja: レストランから出よう。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit," so what is the verb form of that? It's <vocabulary>to exit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want <vocabulary>to exit</vocabulary> the room you're in. Why? Because it has a <reading>de</reading>ad (で) body in it. Seriously. You should exit before someone tries to pin this dead body on you. Quick, leave now!

examples.en: That is not an exit.
examples.ja: そこは出口ではありません。

examples.en: The exit is over there.
examples.ja: 出口はあちらです。

examples.en: This bathroom doesn't have an exit.
examples.ja: このトイレ、出口がないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The mouth you exit out of is just a doorway (I hope), but an easier way to describe this word or concept is to call it an <vocabulary>exit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 出口 is an exception to this rule, however, and uses its kun'yomi readings. There's no particular reason why this is, but oftentimes a "body part" word (like mouth) changes a word to use kun'yomi readings instead of on'yomi ones. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 口 (くち) from learning the vocab, but to remember the reading for 出 you can think the following:

If I exit out this mouth, I'll end up in the ocean (you were swallowed by a whale) and I will surely end up <reading>dea</reading>d (で).

Also keep in mind that because of rendaku, くち becomes ぐち.

examples.en: Please don't water the tree on the right.
examples.ja: 右の木は水をあげないで下さい。

examples.en: Click the button on the bottom right.
examples.ja: 右下のボタンをクリックしてね。

examples.en: On your right is a chart showing the Japanese population.
examples.ja: 右は、日本の人口のチャートです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Look to the <vocabulary>right</vocabulary>. There are <reading>me</reading>at <reading>gee</reading>se (みぎ) over there. What are meat geese, you ask? They're geese made of meat, that sit to the right of you, trying to get you to do bad things. Like the devil/angel motif you see in cartoons. Well there's nothing on your left. And on your right? Just meat geese. Watching you. Waiting. Geese made of meat. Telling you not to do the right thing.

examples.en: Please give me four tomatoes.
examples.ja: トマト四こ下さい。

examples.en: There were four class sections in my international school.
examples.ja: わたしのインターナショナルスクールには四クラスありました。

examples.en: There's a short message written on the fourth page of this book.
examples.ja: この本の四ページには、小さいメッセージがかいてあります。

meaning_mnemonic: This vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji (single alone kanji usually do that!), meaning it means <vocabulary>four</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually uses its kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, though, and use the on'yomi reading. However, four and seven actually use both. We're going to go with the kun'yomi reading here, and since you haven't learned this reading yet, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have to count to <vocabulary>four</vocabulary>. But you're tired. One... two... three... *<reading>YAWN</reading>* ... four. There, you did it. But *yawn* now you can't stop yawning. You're so, so sleepy. Four is too high a number to count without falling asleep.

By the way! Both the reading よん and し are pretty common, but because the on'yomi reading し sounds just like the word for "death," it isn't used as much. Generally when you're just counting (for example, "1, 2, 3, 4..."), you will use the reading し. But when you are counting things or people, you'll use よん. There are exceptions to this, but you'll learn them as they come up.

examples.en: April 1st is April Fool's Day.
examples.ja: 四月一日はエイプリルフールです。

examples.en: Only three more days until April.
examples.ja: 四月まで、あと三日だ。

examples.en: In April, I will try really hard to do my best.
examples.ja: 四月は、力いっぱいがんばります。

meaning_mnemonic: 月 in Japanese means "moon" but it also means "month." Why? Probably because the moon takes about a month to get through its cycles. So, what's the fourth moon of the year? Here's a hint, it's the same as the fourth month of the year: <vocabulary>April</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 月 has two on'yomi readings, but it always uses the がつ reading in the names of the months, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

In <vocabulary>April</vocabulary>, you habitually eat <reading>shee</reading>p <reading>guts</reading> (しがつ). It's a tradition you started many years ago, and now you just can't stop eating sheep guts every April. Delicious!

examples.en: The left contact lens is missing.
examples.ja: 左目のコンタクトレンズがない。

examples.en: I’m left-handed.
examples.ja: わたしは、左ききです。

examples.en: The entrance is the door on your left.
examples.ja: 入り口は左のドアですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Imagine hearing someone to your <vocabulary>left</vocabulary> saying, "<reading>Hi Da'ri</reading>!" (ひだり) which is supposed to be "Hi There," or "Hi Dearie." You turn left and there's no one there. You hear it again, "Hi Da'ri!" Keep turning to the left until you find the person saying hi to you.

examples.en: This book, please.
examples.ja: この本、下さい。

examples.en: This book has hints on how to get better at taking quizzes.
examples.ja: この本にはクイズが上手になるためのヒントがかいてある。

examples.en: My oven has a lot of books in it.
examples.ja: うちのオーブンには本がたくさん入ってるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: This vocab word is exactly the same as its parent kanji, including its meaning as well: <vocabulary>book</vocabulary>. It doesn't have those other meanings though, when it's just 本 alone, it's just a book.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the single kanji it comes from.

examples.en: Japanese curry is delicious.
examples.ja: 日本のカレーはおいしいです。

examples.en: I'm going to Japan in October.
examples.ja: 十月に日本にいきます。

examples.en: What is the population of Japan?
examples.ja: 日本の人口は、どのくらいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember the secondary meaning of 本 being "origin"? That technically makes this <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji>. Does that sound familiar? Japan is known as the "land of the rising sun", which is why this means <vocabulary>Japan</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. The 本 is read just how you learned it, but the 日 reading is sort of an exception here, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've finally arrived in <vocabulary>Japan</vocabulary> and immediately fall down on your <reading>knee</reading>s (に). After two excruciatingly long flights, you've finally made it. You're here. This is Japan. Now get up off your knees, people are starting to stare.

examples.en: Mom is always right.
examples.ja: ママはいつも正しい。

examples.en: It's true that I went into the hotel on the 3rd.
examples.ja: ぼくが三日にホテルに入ったというのは正しいです。

examples.en: Would you like me to show you how to enter an entrance properly?
examples.ja: 入り口の正しい入り方をおしえてあげましょうか？

meaning_mnemonic: Ending with an い tells you that this word is an い-adjective. So since you know that the kanji <kanji>正</kanji> means "<kanji>correct</kanji>," what is the adjective version of that word? Well, it's also <vocabulary>correct</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses a reading you didn't learn from the kanji. You have to remember the ただ portion in order to read this word, so think about it this way:

After you get the answer <vocabulary>correct</vocabulary> a clown jumps out of nowhere yelling "<reading>Ta-da</reading> (ただ)!!!" Imagine it scaring the crap out of you, too.

examples.en: My task is to correct system errors.
examples.ja: タスクはシステムエラーを正すことです。

examples.en: I corrected the position of the logos on left and right.
examples.ja: 左右のロゴのポジションを正した。

examples.en: That person is a programmer who's dedicated for correcting errors.
examples.ja: あの人はエラーをひたすら正すプログラマーです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word is made up of a kanji with some hiragana attached, ending in an う sound. That means this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "correct," so what is the verb form of that? It would be <vocabulary>to correct</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

After you correct something for someone, you yell out <reading>ta-da</reading> (ただ) very excitedly. Go ahead and imagine yourself doing this a few times to help you to remember.

examples.en: What is this ball?
examples.ja: なんだ、この玉？

examples.en: Pochi was a dog that looked like a round ball.
examples.ja: ポチは、まるで丸い玉のような犬でした。

examples.en: Please kick this ball with all your strength.
examples.ja: この玉を力いっぱいキックして下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
As a single kanji vocab on its own, you know this vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji: <vocabulary>ball</vocabulary>.

玉 can be used for round objects traditionally recognized in Japanese culture, like beads, marbles, pearls, snowballs, and pachinko balls. For balls used in sports, people typically use the katakana word ボール.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji: <reading>たま</reading>.

examples.en: Please give me the round onion.
examples.ja: その丸い玉ねぎ下さい。

examples.en: When I cut the onions, I teared up.
examples.ja: 玉ねぎをきっていたら、なみだが出てきた。

examples.en: Curry without onions is not curry.
examples.ja: 玉ねぎが入ってないカレーはカレーじゃない。

meaning_mnemonic: ねぎ means "onion" in Japanese. But, there are different kinds of onions, right? This happens to be a "ball onion," which is just one of those round ones, like a Walla Walla Sweet <vocabulary>Onion</vocabulary>. Do you know?
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can guess it will probably use the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, that's the reading you learned with the only kanji in this word, so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: There are many frogs in the rice fields.
examples.ja: 田にはカエルがたくさんいますよ。

examples.en: This rice field is Koichi's.
examples.ja: この田はコウイチさんのものです。

examples.en: Could you finish ploughing the rice fields before you propose to me?
examples.ja: プロポーズは田をたがやしてからにしてくれる？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Just keep in mind that compared to 田んぼ, which you learned earlier, this word is more formal and less colloquial.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When you learned the kanji that makes up this word, all you learned was the kun'yomi reading, so you should be good to go.

examples.en: My wedding dress is white.
examples.ja: わたしのウェディングドレスは白です。

examples.en: This white is a creamy white.
examples.ja: この白はクリームっぽい白ですね。

examples.en: White and pink are apparently my lucky colors.
examples.ja: 白とピンクがラッキーカラーなんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:

<vocabulary>White</vocabulary> surrounds you. The <reading>sheer</reading> (しろ) amount of white is overwhelming.

examples.en: I live in Japan with a Caucasian partner.
examples.ja: 日本で白人のパートナーとくらしてます。

examples.en: My mom is Caucasian and my dad is Asian.
examples.ja: ママは白人で、パパはアジア人です。

examples.en: It's not that all white people are great at English.
examples.ja: 白人はみんなえいごが上手なわけではないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word uses <kanji>white</kanji> and <kanji>person</kanji> ... put those together and you have a <vocabulary>white person</vocabulary>, aka a <vocabulary>caucasian</vocabulary> person.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 人 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:
