Imagine a <vocabulary>white person</vocabulary> you know well wearing their favorite pair of <reading>hack</reading>ed up <reading>jean</reading>s (はくじん). This person likes to wear jeans with as many rips and holes in them as possible. Now imagine them wearing only their hacked up jeans. What a sight!

examples.en: Our Husky's eyes are blue.
examples.ja: うちのハスキーは目がブルーです。

examples.en: At that moment, a dog came into sight.
examples.ja: そのとき、犬が目に入った。

examples.en: There's a contact lens under your eye.
examples.ja: 目の下にコンタクトレンズがついてるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

examples.en: Salmon eye balls are tasty too.
examples.ja: サーモンは目玉もおいしいですよ。

examples.en: I was so surprised I thought my eyeballs were going to pop out.
examples.ja: びっくりして目玉が出るかとおもった。

examples.en: The highlight of the sale is tomatoes.
examples.ja: セールの目玉はトマトです。

meaning_mnemonic: What is an <kanji>eye</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji>? Oh wait, that's easy. It's an <vocabulary>eyeball</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. <vocabulary>目玉</vocabulary>, however, is an exception. Perhaps this is because it includes a body part (the eye) in it, which often makes a word switch to kun'yomi readings. Either way, it doesn't matter too much. Both the readings you learned for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi, meaning you should know how to read this one. Just make sure you watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I'm not very good at getting up off the sofa.
examples.ja: ソファから立つのが下手なんです。

examples.en: Please stand up.
examples.ja: それでは、立って下さい。

examples.en: It's hard to stand up when all you do is desk work.
examples.ja: デスクワークばっかりだと立つのがしんどい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" so what is the verb version of that? It's <vocabulary>to stand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
You have to remember the た portion of this word to learn the reading of it. Think of it this way:

You have <vocabulary>to stand up</vocabulary> in order to wave goodbye to someone. When you stand up, you also say <reading>ta</reading>-ta (た)!

examples.en: The meeting on the 2nd was canceled.
examples.ja: 二日のミーティングは、キャンセルしました。

examples.en: It's been two days since the puppy arrived.
examples.ja: 子犬がきてから二日です。

examples.en: I was in Paris only for a couple days.
examples.ja: パリに二日しかいなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Second day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day two</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
reading_mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

The circus is in town this weekend and you can't wait to get there. You want to show off your new <reading>foots car</reading> (ふつか) to all the circus clowns. But you have to use your feet to get it there and it ends up taking you <vocabulary>two days</vocabulary>! Darn this old fashioned foots car!

examples.en: There were many people at the exit.
examples.ja: 出口にたくさんの人々がいた。

examples.en: The people around me don't wear jeans much.
examples.ja: まわりの人々は、あまりジーンズをはきません。

examples.en: Why don't people say "Good morning!" more enthusiastically?
examples.ja: なぜ人々は、もっと力いっぱい「おはよう！」といわないんでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Person</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, why, that's more than one person. It's <vocabulary>people</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word 人 twice, with the second one getting rendaku'd, turning it into びと.

examples.en: It takes a day to get to New York.
examples.ja: ニューヨークまで一日かかる。

examples.en: May 1st is "May Day," right?
examples.ja: 五月一日は「メーデー」ですよね？

examples.en: I want to be a girl just for a day.
examples.ja: 一日だけ女の子になりたいなあ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word has two different meanings. <vocabulary>One day</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>first day</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, those meanings make a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic:
The first meaning is <vocabulary>one day</vocabulary>, and it has the same reading as the kanji you learned, so you should already know this reading.

The reading for ”first day," however, is a big old exception. It doesn’t take the on’yomi or kun’yomi readings, and has its own special (weird) readings. Here’s a mnemonic to help  you remember this one:

On the <vocabulary>first day</vocabulary> of a new relationship you just <reading>tweet a chee</reading>sy (ついたち) line at each other. You're so in love you can't speak normally, so you just use bird calls and cheesy lines to communicate.

examples.en: There is a cosplay event on the 7th.
examples.ja: 七日はコスプレのイベントあります。

examples.en: I quit yoga on day seven.
examples.ja: 七日でヨガはやめた。

examples.en: It took me seven days to get to Florida by boat.
examples.ja: フロリダまでボートで七日もかかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Seventh day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day seven</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

You've been stuck inside working for <vocabulary>seven days</vocabulary> and today you finally have a day off. Your friend asks you if you want to go for a drive but you say, "<reading>Nah, no car</reading> today" (なのか), because you've been cooped up long enough. Seven days is too long to be inside.

examples.en: In Japan, March 3rd is a holiday for girls called "hina matsuri."
examples.ja: 日本では、三月三日は、ひなまつりという女の子のイベントです。

examples.en: I got better at the piano after three days.
examples.ja: 三日でピアノが上手になった。

examples.en: I haven't had any water for three days.
examples.ja: 三日も水をのんでいません。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Third day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day three</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Counting days, however, are an exception (at least up to ten). You need to use the kun'yomi readings to read this word. You already know the kun'yomi reading for 三 from when you learned the word 三つ. Here is a way to remember the reading for 日:

On the <vocabulary>third day</vocabulary> you have to give <reading>me</reading> (み) a ride in your <reading>car</reading> (か). I don't have a car of my own, so don't forget me, okay?

examples.en: On March 9th, that girl turns five years old.
examples.ja: 三月九日に、あの女の子は五才になる。

examples.en: I haven't showered in nine days.
examples.ja: 九日もシャワーをあびてない。

examples.en: I became a Mario Kart master on lesson day nine. Thank you.
examples.ja: レッスン九日でマリオカートのマスターになれました。ありがとう。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Ninth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day nine</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic: Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You learned this reading for 九 when you learned 九つ, so you should be able to read this one too!

examples.en: I'll be on a vacation in Hawaii from the 8th.
examples.ja: 八日からハワイでバケーションなんです。

examples.en: It took eight days to make tonkotsu ramen.
examples.ja: とんこつラーメンをつくるのに八日もかかったよ。

examples.en: The kimchi diet ended after eight days.
examples.ja: キムチダイエットは八日でおわった。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Eighth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day eight</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it uses kun'yomi readings for both the kanji. Think about this word this way:

Every <vocabulary>eighth day</vocabulary> you have to buy <reading>yo</reading>gurt to fuel your <reading>ca</reading>r (ようか). Your car runs on yogurt, but it needs to be refilled every <vocabulary>eight days</vocabulary> to keep running. It's really inconvenient because it's just ONE day more than a week. And a week just feels better. Oh well.

examples.en: There's a sword sale on the 10th.
examples.ja: 十日は刀のセールです。

examples.en: It took me ten days to get to Toronto, Canada.
examples.ja: カナダのトロントへいくのに十日かかった。

examples.en: The highlight of the event on March 10th is karaoke.
examples.ja: 三月十日のイベントの目玉はカラオケです。

meaning_mnemonic: <vocabulary>Tenth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day ten</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic:
Words that count days use an exceptional reading. Even though this is a jukugo word, it actually uses kun’yomi readings. Think about this word this way:

This marks the <vocabulary>tenth day</vocabulary> since this <reading>talker</reading> (とおか) began talking non-stop. Talkers love talking, but this one is getting quite unbearable… Ten days of talking, can you believe it?

Note that とお, generally pronounced "toh" with a long "o" sound, is not a common spelling, and you’ll only see it with a handful of kanji and vocabulary, like in this case. I mean, how often do you encounter a talker who can go on non-stop for ten days? That's pretty rare, right?

examples.en: Let’s learn a lot!
examples.ja: 大いにまなびましょう。

examples.en: The king said to the prince and the princess, "Go ahead and use a lot of the citizens' tax money."
examples.ja: 王は王子と王女に、「大いにこくみんのぜいきんをつかっていいぞ」といった。

examples.en: Please drink a lot today.
examples.ja: きょうは大いにのみたまえ。

meaning_mnemonic: This words is all about doing something in a big way. Particle に on the end tells us its an adverb, meaning that it describes how an action is carried out. It can mean very, a lot of, or greatly, depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned 大きい. If you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

examples.en: There are a lot of koi fish in the water.
examples.ja: 水中にコイがたくさんいる。

examples.en: This camera is an underwater camera.
examples.ja: このカメラは、水中カメラです。

examples.en: Do you want to play underwater mahjong with me?
examples.ja: 水中マージャンやらない？

meaning_mnemonic: If you're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of a bunch of <kanji>water</kanji>, then you're most likely <vocabulary>underwater</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The jacket has pockets on the left and the right.
examples.ja: ジャケットの左右にはポケットがあります。

examples.en: Make a U-turn after looking left and right.
examples.ja: 左右をみてからUターンしてね。

examples.en: The cost depends on the size of the Japanese population.
examples.ja: コストは日本の人口の大きさに左右されます。

examples.en: That really depends on the weather.
examples.ja: それは大いにてんきに左右される。

meaning_mnemonic: Put <kanji>left</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji> together and you end up with <vocabulary>left and right</vocabulary>! Just make sure you say them in the right order!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please enter your social security number here.
examples.ja: ここにソーシャルセキュリティナンバーを入力して下さい。

examples.en: These three are data-entry professionals.
examples.ja: この三人はデータ入力のプロだよ。

examples.en: People who can do "Romaji input" and "Kana input" are sexy, right?
examples.ja: 「Romaji入力」と「かな入力」ができる人ってセクシーだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Enter</kanji> something with all your <kanji>strength</kanji> and you will look down to see that what you're doing is <vocabulary>input</vocabulary>ting data. You're inputting it right now! Into this site! The answers you <vocabulary>enter</vocabulary> into WaniKani with all your strength can be said with this word. Wow. Full circle already, and you're only on level 2. Look at you go!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Where you work, <vocabulary>input</vocabulary>ting things earns you <reading>new</reading> <reading>lock</reading>s (にゅうりょく). Not only is your job only about <vocabulary>enter</vocabulary>ing things into a computer, you're also paid exclusively in new locks. Maybe consider a career change!

examples.en: There are a lot of rice paddies in Asia.
examples.ja: アジアには田んぼがたくさんある。

examples.en: This is a rice field for jasmine rice.
examples.ja: これはジャスミンライスの田んぼです。

examples.en: Please do not enter the paddy in high heels.
examples.ja: 田んぼにハイヒールで入らないで下さい。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know that the kanji 田 means <kanji>rice paddy</kanji>, so it should be easy to work out that this word also means <vocabulary>rice paddy</vocabulary>.

田んぼ is a common way to say "rice paddy," especially in casual conversation. You can tell because if you ever came across a ju<reading>mbo</reading> (んぼ) rice paddy, you'd probably say something like, "Whoa, that's one jumbo 田んぼ!" When a 田んぼ is that jumbo, the surprise makes your speech naturally more relaxed and informal.
reading_mnemonic: This word has hiragana attached to the kanji, which is a good sign that the reading is kun'yomi. You learned that reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be good to go.

examples.en: Good morning, Miho-chan!
examples.ja: ミホちゃん、おはよう！

examples.en: I texted "good morning" to Mike.
examples.ja: マイクに「おはよう」とメールをした。

examples.en: Ugh, I'm sleepy... morning.
examples.ja: うーっ、ねむいー、おはよう。

meaning_mnemonic:
From <reading>Ohio</reading> (おはよう), you shout <vocabulary>good morning</vocabulary>. Why Ohio? Because that's where you woke up this morning. Imagine yourself waking up in Ohio, and wishing everyone "good morning" at the top of your lungs.

おはよう is a casual way to say "good morning." It can also be written in kanji, but hiragana is much more common.

examples.en: Did you book a hotel already?
examples.ja: ホテル、もうとった？

examples.en: I'm just about to check out of the hotel.
examples.ja: 今、ホテルをチェックアウトするところ。

examples.en: Which hotel will you stay at?
examples.ja: どこのホテルにステイするの？

meaning_mnemonic:
ホテル comes from the English word <vocabulary>hotel</vocabulary> and the meaning is exactly the same!

The only thing to watch out for is that the "l" on the end becomes ル, because that's the closest sound in Japanese.
